awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: High-Performance Biocatalytic Membranes with Self-Contained Radical Polymer Mediators for Water Reclamation and Reuse
awd_abstract_narration:
Access to clean water is among the greatest engineering challenges of the 21st century. Efficient use of existing freshwater resources is a primary strategy to address this challenge. However, current societal needs cannot be met without additional water from sources like brackish water and wastewater. Successful reclamation and reuse of these water sources depends on the development of technologies to ensure these waters are fit for use. This project addresses this need using natural enzymes to degrade toxic contaminants present in water. These highly-efficient biological catalysts will be formulated into biocatalytic membranes using recent advances in the fields of polymer chemistry and additive manufacturing. Biocatalytic inks that contain enzymes and other tailor-made functional components will be deposited onto nanoporous membrane supports in a modular fashion. The modular design can be customized for specific needs by changing the target enzymes and/or polymer mediators. Successful development of this technology will help address the critical challenges of the Nation to ensure the supply of safe, clean, and sustainable water resources. Broader impacts for society will result from this project by training the next generation of interdisciplinary scientists and engineers to address the challenge of supplying water to the Nation.

Although efficient use of existing freshwater resources is a primary strategy to supply the Nation's water in the face of increasing demand, current societal needs cannot be met without additional water from sources like brackish water and wastewater. Successful reclamation and reuse of these water sources depends on the development of technologies to ensure these waters are fit for use. Enzyme biocatalysis is a promising platform to address this need. Such platforms require small molecular weight redox-active mediators to facilitate the enzymatic degradation of recalcitrant micropollutants. Although these small molecules provide clear benefits, they are costly and can leach from processes necessitating frequent replenishment. Therefore, it is critical to eliminate mediator washout to make this water treatment technology feasible. The overall goal of this project is to generate the scientific knowledge that enables the design and fabrication of high-performance biocatalytic membranes. This will be done by identifying control factors in the design of radical polymer-based macromolecular mediators and elucidating the processing-structure-property relationships that govern their co-deposition with enzymes on nanoporous supports. The specific research tasks to achieve this goal are to: 1) identify macromolecular mediator designs that promote the efficient degradation of micropollutants while preventing mediator washout; 2) elucidate the processing-structure-property relationships for biocatalytic membranes to correlate membrane support architecture with the biocatalytic and transport properties; and 3) evaluate biocatalytic membrane performance over the course of multiple recover and reuse cycles to inform membrane design for field-relevant applications. Successful completion of this research will address gaps in our knowledge on biocatalytic membrane design and manufacture. This knowledge will have broad impact in the fields of additive manufacturing as well as water treatment. The Nation will further benefit by the training of interdisciplinary scientists and engineers with the expertise necessary to advance the water technology landscape of the United States.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Water scarcity and pollution are among the greatest engineering challenges of the 21st century. While the improved use of existing freshwater sources can assist in meeting the growing demand for clean water, these resources are already stressed and cannot be stretched to meet the demands of society. Therefore, the production of clean water from non-traditional sources, such as brackish water and wastewater, is the only means by which to increase water supplies to the level required. In this regard, the continued development of technologies to reclaim water from contaminated resources is of the utmost importance. In particular, the removal of chemicals that are harmful to the environment and human health is a critical need in the development of water reclamation technologies. Unfortunately, state-of-the-art treatment technologies are energy-intensive, chemically-intensive, and/or generate unwanted by-products. Conversely, enzymes, which are highly-efficient biological catalysts that can degrade toxic compounds to benign products, are a promising platform for the development of water reclamation processes. Notably, biocatalytic processes have been demonstrated for applications where efficient synthetic methods have yet to be developed. Moreover, enzyme biocatalysis: (i) demonstrates high catalytic efficiency at ambient temperature and pressure, (ii) generates no toxic byproducts, and (iii) has low energy requirements. While enzyme biocatalysis holds great promise as a “green chemistry” alternative for beneficial chemical transformations, using free enzymes in solution for contaminant removal is not suitable or economical due to the low stability, non-reusability, and the high costs associated with a single use for these materials. Additionally, the presence of redox mediators is often required to enable the oxidation of recalcitrant compounds that are not directly oxidized by the enzyme alone. The high cost and toxicity of these small molecule mediators further hamper the sustainability of enzyme biocatalysis. As such, this effort aimed to address these key scientific opportunities to further water purification technologies.

 

Through the course of this award, the project established the redox-active polymer materials required to start the biocatalytic process in these designer membranes, which were fabricated and evaluated through our collaborators at the University of Notre Dame. The establishment of our design principles relied on the concept that the materials needed to be printable, be resistant to dissolution in aqueous solutions, be robust to a range of environmental conditions, and have long stability in terms of their redox cycling behavior. The syntheses of materials with these key properties occurred through the incorporation of open-shell (i.e., radical groups) within the macromolecular framework of radical polymers. These radical polymers were often synthesized to either have a crosslinkable moiety attached to the polymer backbone through covalent chemistry and/or as a single moiety within a block polymer framework to increase the robustness of the materials during practical operational conditions. For instance, we tailored the synthesis of the macromolecules to allow for an open-shell–closed-shell diblock copolymer to be synthesized in a ready manner to generate materials with a range of closed-shell block volume fractions to elucidate how molecular structure connects to the rheological and solid-state structural properties of the resultant thin films that were used as biocatalytic membranes. Additionally, when these macromolecular design principles were implemented, it allowed the radical polymer-based materials to be incorporated into inks that were used for membrane printing. Due to these materials breakthroughs and our partnership with collaborators at the University of Notre Dame, the team took great strides in advancing towards next-generation water purification devices. In this way, the fundamental materials chemistry paradigms introduced here will enable technologies that will aid in addressing one of the key current societal grand challenges.

In addition to the outcomes associated with laboratory work, this project was instrumental in advancing key training and educational programs as well, although some of the in-person components of these training programs did not occur due to the global pandemic. However, two graduate students, including 1 Latina/Latinx woman, were trained due to this award. During this award, the doctoral students were trained on experimental techniques that improved their polymer chemistry, polymer physics, and transport phenomena knowledge to a significant degree. For instance, one of the students on the project is a PhD student in the Department of Chemistry. As such, he has had to come up to speed quickly on many chemical engineering principles (e.g., mass transport) such that he has delivered new materials designs that aid in the end-use functionality of the biocatalytic membranes. Additionally, in the final year of the project, undergraduate students were allowed back into the laboratories, and these students participated in the project as researchers for the project. In this way, they supplemented their online coursework training that occurred during the pandemic with much-desired hands-on experimentation in a meaningful manner. Through these efforts, it is our sincere hope that this work has significantly improved the technology and training landscape of the United States.


Last Modified: 12/27/2022
Modified by: David S Corti
